00017 package WeBWorK::Form::TiedParam;
00018 
00019 # See package WeBWorK::Form, below.
00020 
00021 use strict;
00022 use warnings;
00023 
00024 sub TIESCALAR ($$$) {
00025     my ($invocant, $f, $param) = @_;
00026     my $class = ref($invocant) || $invocant;
00027     my $self = {
00028         f => $f,
00029         param => $param,
00030     };
00031     
00032     return bless $self, $class;
00033 }
00034 
00035 sub FETCH {
00036     my $self = shift;
00037     my $f = $self->{f};
00038     my $param = $self->{param};
00039     return $f->param($param);
00040 }
00041 
00042 sub STORE {
00043     my $self = shift;
00044     my @values = @_;
00045     my $f = $self->{f};
00046     my $param = $self->{param};
00047     $f->param($param, @values);
00048 }

00052 package WeBWorK::Form;
00053 
00054 =head1 NAME
00055 
00056 WeBWorK::Form - extract form input from an Apache::Request and provide an
00057 interface to it.
00058 
00059 =cut

00061 use strict;
00062 use warnings;
00063 
00064 sub new {
00065     #print "new called with \@_ = ( " . (join ", ", @_)  . " )\n";
00066     my ($invocant, $r) = @_;
00067     my $class = ref($invocant) || $invocant;
00068     my $self = {};
00069 
00070     return bless $self, $class;
00071 }
00072 
00073 sub new_from_paramable ($$) {
00074     my ($invocant, $r) = @_;
00075     my $class = ref($invocant) || $invocant;
00076     my $self = {};
00077 
00078     # list of param names
00079     my @params = $r->param;
00080     foreach my $key (@params) {
00081         $self->{$key} = [ $r->param($key) ];
00082     }
00083 
00084     return bless $self, $class;
00085 }
00086 
00087 sub new_test {
00088     my ($invocant, $r) = @_;
00089     my $class = ref($invocant) || $invocant;
00090     my $self = {
00091         a => [qw(aa ab ac)],
00092         b => [ "bcontents" ],
00093         c => [ "cc", "ccd" ],
00094         d => [ "what d has" ],
00095     };
00096 
00097     return bless $self, $class;
00098 }
00099 
00100 # @keys = $f->param
00101 # $value = $f->param("key")
00102 # @values = $f->param("key")
00103 # $f->param("key", "value")
00104 # $f->param(key => [qw(val1 val2 val3)]
00105 # $f->param(key => "val1", "val2", "val3");
00106 
00107 # Oh, there I go again with multiple returns all over.  To be fair,
00108 # any function that emulates CGI::param has to do a few different things
00109 # in different contexts.
00110 sub param {
00111     my ($self, $param, @values) = @_;
00112     
00113     # Called with one argument.  Return keys.
00114     if (!defined $param) {
00115         return keys %$self;
00116     }
00117     
00118     # called with three arguments.  Set a value, then fall through
00119     if (scalar(@values)) {
00120         if (ref $values[0]) {
00121             $self->{$param} = $values[0];
00122         } else {
00123             $self->{$param} = [ @values ];
00124         }
00125     }
00126     
00127     # Called with 2+ arguments.  Return requested value
00128     if (wantarray) {
00129         return @{$self->{$param}};
00130     } else {
00131         return $self->{$param}[0];
00132     }
00133 }
00134 
00135 # lparam("key") will return the same value as param("key"), but it returns
00136 # it as a scalar lvalue, so that you can assign strings or arrayrefs to the
00137 # function call like this: $form->lparam("foo") = "bar" or
00138 # $form->lparam("foo") = [qw(bar baz blah)].
00139 # This function absolutely requires 5.6, which is where :lvalue comes from.
00140 sub lparam($$) : lvalue {
00141     tie my $lvalue, 'WeBWorK::Form::TiedParam', shift, shift;
00142     $lvalue;
00143 }
00144 
00145 sub delete {
00146     my ($self, $param) = @_;
00147     CORE::delete $self->{$param};
00148 }
00149 
00150 sub Delete {
00151     my $self = shift;
00152     $self->delete(@_);
00153 }
00154 
00155 sub printable {
00156     my $self = shift;
00157     my $printedform = "";
00158     foreach my $key ($self->param) {
00159         $printedform .= "[$key]\n";
00160         foreach my $value ($self->param($key)) {
00161             $printedform .= "$value\n";
00162         }
00163         $printedform .= "\n";
00164     }
00165     
00166     return $printedform;
00167 }
00168 
00169 # This partially supports the :cgi-lib Vars() interface, a-la CGI.pm.  Not
00170 # supported is being called in scalar context, which in CGI.pm returned a
00171 # tied hashref to the original form data.  WeBWorK didn't need that, so I
00172 # didn't add it.  If you're feeling industrious...
00173 
00174 #FIXME?  I originally changed   join("\0",....)  to join(\0, ....) since I'm pretty sure that what was desired
00175 # was a string separated by nulls.   If one of the items in the list began with a number  eg 14
00176 # you would get    \014....\0name...\0   etc.  I think \0name evaluates properly but I'm pretty
00177 # sure that \014 does not.
00178 #
00179 # Then I backed out of the change until this gets checked more thoroughly by Sam
00180 # -- Mike
00181 
00182 sub Vars {
00183     my $self = shift;
00184     my %varsFormat = ();
00185     foreach my $key ($self->param) {
00186         $varsFormat{$key} = join "\0", $self->param($key);
00187     }
00188     
00189     return %varsFormat; 
00190 }
